results.title: Fishtank
results.material_description: Single channel moving image, colour and audio
results.brief_description:
A high-rise flat in the U.K. Midlands. Ray is the father who drinks, Liz the mother, Jason the brother. There are some animals and the brother kills flies. The older brother films them with his handycam - intently observing whatever is going on.

In 1996 Richard Billingham’s ‘Ray’s a Laugh’ was hailed as the photo book of the decade. His photographs were one of the talking points of ‘Sensation’. Billingham has now made ‘Fishtank’, a commission for television by Artangel in collaboration with film-maker Adam Curtis and Illuminations TV for BBC2’s acclaimed TV series. The ‘video verite’ of Fishtank is contained within the compressed space/fishtank of the flat. Sometimes they talk, sometimes they argue. Billingham’s film registers the emotional temperature of this space and the family who live there with a closeness that transcends camera conventions. Like the paintings of Lucian Freud, Billingham crafts a terrible beauty from the landscape of family life and its patterns of pathos, despair and hope.

results.title: The Bad society
results.brief_description: In December 1976, 16,000 people converged at the Cotter River in Canberra for the “Down to earth” festival; a conference on alternative lifestyles. In attendance were Reverend George Davies, Dr. Jim Cairns, Dr. Jim Falk as well as thousands of counter culture followers. This documentary explores the festival and the themes of politics and social change. The Philisophy of Ex Deputy Prime Minister, Dr. Jim Cairns is particularly focussed on with its emphasis on how a nation state creates a ‘bad society’ and how communal life and a counter culture lifestyle forms the only radicalism against society.

results.title: Tramways
results.creator_credit: Michael Bau, Gunzel and Leonie Dickinson
results.brief_description: A warm hearted look at the people of Melbourne, their trams and their passion. Delves into the fascination with a mode of transport that carries passengers in the 19990’s on 1930’s vehicles.
results.description: A warm hearted look at the people of Melbourne, their trams and their passion. Delves into the fascination with a mode of transport that carries passengers in the 19990’s on 1930’s vehicles.

results.title: For today, for tomorrow: new choices for older Australians
results.creator_credit: Commonwealth Department of Community Services and Health in association with National Recording Studios Canberra and Maria Taylor
results.brief_description: Through the lives of five older Australians, this program explores the Commonwealth Governments’ new directions for aged care services. The services featured include Home & Community Care services that allow people to remain in their own homes, the Geriatric Assessment Teams that assist individuals and their families in making informed choices and then co-ordinate the services, and a new range of choices for hostels and nursing homes. Discusses programs that address special needs such as those of older migrants. Narrated by June Salter.
results.title_for_label: For today, for tomorrow: new choices for older Australians

results.title: Go for it!
results.creator_credit: Barwon Youth Employment Office for the Employment Access Program, Community Services Victoria and Clayton Jacobson
results.brief_description: A program aimed at young disadvantaged youth in the labour market, particularly those attending Youth Training Centres, Youth Welfare Services, living in hostels or in the care and custody of Community Services Victoria. Highlights young people succeeding in various jobs and through interviews discusses how they found employment, their expectations and experiences in the workforce.

results.title: Appearances can deceive: offenders with intellectual disabilities
results.creator_credit: Suzanne Baker, Suzanne Baker Productions, New South Wales. Premier's Dept. Disability Services Co-ordination Unit, New South Wales Film Corporation and Bob Kingsbury
results.brief_description: Designed to improve awareness of intellectually disabled offenders in the criminal justice system, given that this group comprise a disproportionate percentage of both the prison population and juvenile offenders held in institutions. Re-enacts a shop lifting offence by an intellectually disabled youth and follows the case from initial apprehension by the store detective and police interviewing to the arrest and court proceedings. Emphasises the importance of liason with community agencies.
results.title_for_label: Appearances can deceive: offenders with intellectual disabilities

results.title: In search of a landscape
results.creator_credit: Hannah Dunne and Swinburne Institute of Technology. Film and Television School
results.brief_description: The pre-performance preparations by Hannah Dunne and her dance troupe as they practice for their performance of “In search of a landscape”. Hannah describes to the viewer how she arrived at the name for this particular piece. NB: This video was donated by the performer and has a grainy quality. You do not need to adjust your machine.

results.title: Judah Waten
results.creator_credit: Elisabeth Knight, Film Australia and Darrelyn Gunzburg
results.brief_description: In an interview conducted at his home in Victoria in December 1982, Judah Waten discusses his writing, his life, his Jewish background, political views and Russian, Yiddish and Australian influences on his writing, including the experiences of migrants. This is interspersed with brief remarks by a number of his friends, including Manning Clark, Justice Judith Cohen and Alan Marshall.

results.title: Organics: food for thought
results.creator_credit: Mike Laker, Victoria. Dept. of Agriculture and Rural Affairs and Jim Testa
results.brief_description: Organic farmers work with nature rather than against it, a process of positive cooperation with the soil, without the intervention of chemicals, in order to produce a quality product. Filmed on location in Victoria, this video covers the production, marketing, export potential and labelling of organic produce in Australia. It features citrus grower, Robert Ridgewell; bio-dynamic wheat/sheep farmer, John Greenwood; vegetable grower, Neville Cann and Ian Diamond, organic wholesaler.
